descript.abstract: Mapping of terrestrial vertebrates rests upon linking a spatial representation of species-habitat matrices to geographic distribution. Each model is a combination of distribution region-grown from county occurrence information in association with contiguous appropriate habitats. Ranges for all species were based on county boundaries. Habitats were based on a raster CO-GAP 100 ha MMU land cover data set, with aquatic and riparian habitats added in from USGS DLG-coverages directly or through modeling. Habitat association information was obtained from the Colorado Division of Wildlife - Colorado Wildlife Species Database with updates from major scientific literature. This portion of the Colorado Gap Analysis Project produced predicted distribution maps for 597 species.
descript.purpose: This data was prepared in compliance with the National GAP effort. Distributions of 18 amphibians, 48 reptiles, 408 birds and 123 mammals were predicted by county using a variety of sources. Bird distributions were generated from published and unpublished sources; most notably the Colorado Wildlife Species Database, and from field reports of the Colorado Bird Atlas Project and Denver Museum of Natural History publication Colorado Birds. Mammal distributions were generated from the Colorado Wildlife Species Database, with cross-checks with the Fitzgerald, Meaney and Armstrong publication, Mammals of Colorado. Amphibian and reptile distributions came from the Colorado Wildlife Species Database, and cross-checked with Hammerson's Reptiles of Colorado. All terrestrial taxa county constraint models benefitted from review of the Colorado Division of Wildlife's Scientific Collections Permit Database (SCICOLL). Habitat relationships for all terrestrial vertebrates were taken from the Colorado Wildlife Species Database and most recent published scientific literature on each taxa, with review of collected relationships by species experts. These habitat relationships were cross-linked to one or several of the 52 land cover/vegetation types delineated on the Colorado Gap Analysis Project land cover map. Predicted distribution maps were produced for each species (or select sub-species) based on county of occurrence and habitat affinities.

status.update: Over next 5 years; under SW-ReGAP Project

idinfo.useconst: This database in not intended for site-specific analyses. Interpretations derived from its use are suited for regional and planning purposes only. Acknowledgment of Colorado Division of Wildlife and the Colorado Gap Analysis Project is appreciated.

cntinfo.cntinst: All standard CO-GAP vertebrate modeling data may be obtained on the CD-ROM included with the Gap Standard Distribution CDs to be distributed by the USGS - Biological Resources Division, National Gap Analysis office.

idinfo.datacred: Schrupp, D.L., L.E. O'Brien, J. Kindler, J. Lowsky, M. Wunder, C. Buoy, L. Satcowitz, T. G. Thompson, J. Stark.

attracc.attraccr: Thematic accuracy of vertebrate models were tested and presented, in the form of tables in the final report and may be obtained at http://ndis.nrel.colostate.edu/cogap/report/dwnldrpt.html

dataqual.complete: Models were developed for 597 species of amphibians (18), reptiles (48), birds (408) and mammals (123), focusing on native and established non-native species, not considered incidental or accidental to Colorado.

procstep.procdesc: For a full description of the procedures involved in constructing this database please refer to the CO-GAP Final Report chapter on "Predicted Animal Distributions and Species Richness" at the URL: http://ndis.nrel.colostate.edu/cogap/report/dwnldrpt.html

enttyp.enttypd: Modeled habitat and associated stewardship class (1or2 or 3or4)
enttyp.enttypds: CO-GAP vertebrate habitat ranking methodologies - see Final Report

attr.attrdefs: CO-Gap vertebrate habitat modeling methodologies - see Final Report

cntinfo.cntinst: All standard CO-GAP vertebrate modeling data may be obtained on the CD-ROM included with the Gap Standard Distribution CDs to be distributed by the USGS - Biological Resources Division, National Gap Analysis office.

Any views and opinions of authors expressed herein do not necessarily state or reflect those of the State of Colorado. Data on this media may have been derived from federal agencies or from other external sources or from data developed by the Colorado Division of Wildlife. In those cases where data has been translated from one format to another or initially developed from map or other sources the Colorado Division of Wildlife has made all reasonable efforts to preserve the data quality as originally developed, however no warranty, expressed or implied, is made by the Colorado Division of Wildlife as to the completeness or accuracy of the data and related materials. The act of distribution does not constitute any such warranty, and no responsibility is assumed by the Colorado Division of Wildlife in the use of this data, or related materials.
